components.title: Module  3 : Scope and intensity of effort required in an ongoing PB program or a new program to meet the needs for new planting materials in the target production areas for the crop/crop group being considered

components.content: Assessment 5 :Organizational capital support, policy, laws & regulations for seed system
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1.Organizational capital support, policy, laws & regulations for seed systems

questions.label: 1. Rate the effect that national or regional policy boards have on crop improvement
2. Rate the effect that reliable public funding for plant breeding research and cultivar development has on crop improvement
3. Rate the effect that the National Seed Act (name, identification, seed purity, minimum germination, and compulsory varietal regulation) has on crop improvement
4. Rate the effect that the Plant Quarantine Act (import/export standards) has on crop improvement
5. Rate the effect that biosafety protocols governing testing, release and sale of transgenic plant materials has on crop improvement
6. Rate the effect that intellectual property protections such as UPOV breeders’ rights, farmers’ rights, patents, etc. has on crop improvement
7. Rate the effect that governmental incentive program(s) for investment in agriculture research and development has on crop improvement
8. Rate the effect that national/state credit programs for farmers that affects adoption/use of new plant cultivars has on crop improvement

components.label: For the following questions, consider your crop in the country and region(s) for which you are breeding new cultivars
9. What overall grade would you give the above policies, laws, or regulations with respect to crop improvement
page9M3A5-assessment5Panel

components.title: Module  3 : Scope and intensity of effort required in an ongoing PB program or a new program to meet the needs for new planting materials in the target production areas for the crop/crop group being considered
components.label: page10M3A6-assessment6

components.content: Assessment 6 :Social and organizational capital resources, bi-directional communication
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1.Social and organizational capital resources, bi-directional communication

questions.label: 1. Rate the effectiveness that co-ops, farmers' groups and other similar organizations have on crop improvement
2. Rate the effectiveness of procedures for farmers/stakeholders to communicate with the government about their needs with respect to crop improvement
3. Rate the effectiveness of extension or other services that provide education and training to farmers to become seed distribution entrepreneurs
4. Rate the effectiveness of extension services' or other outreach services' ability to provide relevant information to farmers about performance of new crop cultivars in a timely manner
5. Rate the effectiveness of extension or other service providers with respect to providing information about credit to farmers for seed and input purchases
6. Rate the extent to which extension or other service providers inform farmers about cropping systems and optimal use of new or improved cultivars
7. Rate the effectiveness of extension or other service providers to inform farmers about the marketing of farm commodities from this crop
8. Rate the effectiveness of this center and this breeding program to develop and distribute new cultivars of this crop

components.label: For the following questions, consider your crop in the country and region(s) for which you are breeding new cultivars
9. In a summary, please describe how the social, organizational, and capital resources benefit farmers and breeding programs in your country/region

components.title: Module  3 : Scope and intensity of effort required in an ongoing PB program or a new program to meet the needs for new planting materials in the target production areas for the crop/crop group being considered
components.label: page11M3A7-assessment7

components.content: Assessment 7 :Recommendation for the intensity and scope of a plant breeding program
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1.Recommendation for the intensity and scope of a plant breeding program

components.label: Recommend the intensity and scope of a plant breeding program for your crop based on: crop value and product demand, supply, demand and needs for planting materials of improved cultivars; and social and organizational capital resources available to support plant breeding in your country/region

questions.label: 1. Rate the justification for a plant breeding program for improvement based on the crop value and product demand in

2. Rate the justification for a plant breeding program for improvement based on supply and demand for planting materials in the primary production areas of . Consider supply from all viable sources in the public and private sectors
3. Rate the justification for a plant breeding program for improvement based on the unmet needs for genetically improved cultivars of in the primary production areas of
4. Rate the sufficiency and adequacy of organizational capital support, e.g., policy, laws, regulations etc. for a continuing (or new) plant breeding program for your crop
5. Rate the sufficiency and adequacy of social capital and bi-lateral communication networks for a continuing (or new) plant breeding program for your crop
6. What is recommended for the level of intensity and scope of a plant breeding program in your organization for in?

components.label: Low intensity program with limited scope of objectives and activities:
Medium intensity program with strategically placed scope of objectives and activities:
High intensity program with broad scope of objectives and activities:

components.title: Module  4 : Plant breeding program activities, accomplishments and opportunities
components.label: page15M4A9a-assessment9a

components.content: Assessment 9a :Current Breeding program goals and objectives
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1.Current Breeding Programs (BP) Goals and Objectives

components.label: 1. When did the current breeding program for this crop start at this station?
2. State the current overall Breeding Program goals
3. How are the program goals and objectives established and how are they evaluated?
4. List the current 5 year objectives for cultivar development and release
5. List the current 10 year objectives for cultivar development and release
6. How well are these goals and objectives being met?
7. Have the current goals and objectives changed over time from the programs beginning, and if so how?

components.title: Module  4 : Plant breeding program activities, accomplishments and opportunities
components.label: page16M4A9b-assessment9b

components.content: Assessment 9b :Breeding Priorities
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1. Breeding Priorities

components.content: Following are a set of interconnected questions about priorities in this PB program for this country and regions:
components.label: Content

1. How many key production areas are there for the crop and of these, how many areas have distinct crossing programs devoted to them? Where are those programs located, i.e., the crossing and selection done?
2. Are particular farming systems targeted, e.g., small vs. large, high input vs. low input, etc. ? Please elaborate

3. Of the key production areas identified in Assessment 2, what are the important primary traits common to all/most areas that are specifically selected for (as opposed to only evaluated for). Specify these under either general categories or specific traits, e.g., yield, biotic stress, abiotic stress, quality, disease resistance, etc

4. Have program priorities changed over time from the beginning of the program? How often are priorities altered and what is the basis for change? Has adoption of previously released varieties affected these changing priorities?
5. Has a systematic priority setting been done for breeding targets using such things as GIS, yield constraint distributions, and economic return analysis? Has this influenced budget allocations?
6. What kind of strategy does this program use to anticipate the needs of clients and users in 5, 10 or 15 years?

7. For new cultivars coming from your breeding program, how are they distributed to farmers? What sort of follow-up is used to determine how well they are performing in farmers' fields, how widely they are grown, and what are the perceive/real strengths
8. How are breeding priorities and activities affected by funding, personnel available, and crop mandates?

components.title: Module  4: Plant breeding program activities, accomplishments and opportunities
components.label: page17M4A9c-assessment9c

components.content: Assessment 9c: Breeding Practices
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1. Breeding Practices

components.content: <b>1. Over the last two five-year periods, what percentage of program’s personnel and resources is devoted to the following (Total should add to 100% even though program may have other activities):
components.label: Content
Making crosses and evaluating own segregating populations for line development (i.e., either new parents of hybrid cultivars, of pureline cultivars, of clonal cultivars)
Evaluating segregating populations from other breeding programs for line development (i.e., either new parents of hybrid cultivars, of pureline cultivars, of clonal cultivars)
Evaluating fixed lines from other breeding programs for (i.e., either new parents of hybrid cultivars, of pureline cultivars, of clonal cultivars)
Testing potential new cultivars made from the lines developed from the previous sources
Pre-breeding (e.g., developing improved populations or germplasm for later use in line and cultivar development. (specify)
Total

validate.customMessage: The percentages should add up to 100%.

components.content: <b>2. In your crossing and selection program, which breeding method(s) do you use:
components.label: Content

values.label: Controlled crosses e.g., 2-parent crosses, full and half-sib crosses, self pollinations
Test crosses for general and specific combining ability

components.label: 3. What method do you use to maintain breeding records, e.g, pedigrees, test results, etc.

components.content: <b>11. What are the number of seasons before varieties are put into multi-locational varietal trial? Number of locations? Number of varieties evaluated? What is current check?
components.label: Content
4. Where are crosses among parents made to produce segregating populations, in the field, in a protected structure (e.g., a screen house, plastic house etc.)
5. What is the approx. number of different parents in your crossing block? (If more than one crossing block, specify each one)
6. What are the number of plants in the populations you commonly use for first selection (i.e., in a segregating F2 population) and what is the percentage selected for advancement each cycle?
7. How many selection cycles do you complete each year at your primary breeding station? Do you use other locations for selection during each year to increase breeding efficiency?
8. How many different environments are progeny selected in? Different field environments? In protected structures (e.g., screening seedlings for disease resistance, etc.)
9. How many primary traits are selected for (i.e., where selection pressure is assured)?
10. What are number of seasons before progeny (new lines, hybrids, etc. ) reach replicated yield trial and number of locations? How many progeny reach this stage?
For multi-locational field trials, what access do you have to public-supported field stations? Are these adequate for your trial needs?
12. Have you heard of and/or do you use Participatory Plant Breeding in your breeding program? At what stage and how do you involve farmers?
13. Do you use tissue culture at any stage in your breeding program? If yes, at what stage?

14. Does your institute have a capacity for use of Marker Assisted Breeding (MAB)? Do you use it in your breeding program? For marker-assisted parental selection, marker-assisted seedling selection, marker-assisted backcross, helping to fix parental lines
15. As a breeder, how do you maintain professional interactions? Use of the internet, through regional crop meetings, national and international conferences, other? Approx frequency of each?
16. Please make any additional comments below

components.title: Module4: Plant breeding program activities, accomplishments and opportunities
components.label: page18M4A9d-assessment9d

components.content: Assessment 9d :Germplasm resources
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1. Breeding Practices

components.content:
1. For your current breeding program:
Of the parents in your crossing block, what percentage come from the following sources (20 = 20%; everything should total 100 for 100%)
components.label: Content
Local land races—own program or institute collection
Domestically developed lines from your program or others in country (or region?)
CGIAR developed lines via collaborative programs
Total

validate.customMessage: The percentages should add up to 100%.

components.content:
3. Could you provide the same information for your crossing program from 10 years ago
Of the parents in your crossing block, what percentage come from the following sources (20 = 20%; everything should total 100 for 100%)
components.label: Content
Local land races—own program or institute collection
Domestically developed lines from your program or others in country (or region?)
CGIAR developed lines via collaborative programs
Total

validate.customMessage: The percentages should add up to 100%.

components.content:
4. For the 5-10 principal (most important) traits that are selected for in the breeding program, what is the best or two best sources for that trait:
• List traits and source as specified above
components.label: Content
2. Have material accessed from germplasm banks required a material transfer agreement? Have you found difficulty in meeting the requirements of those agreements?
For any of these traits, do you have access to molecular markers that you can use for marker-assisted selection? Do you plan to use MAS for improving any of these traits?
5. If/when available, could you use a transgenic parent in your breeding program?
6. Can you provide the pedigree of the principal domestically developed lines used as parents in your crossing program?

components.title: Module  4 : Plant breeding program activities, accomplishments and opportunities
components.label: page19M4A9e-assessment9e

components.content: Assessment 9e :Delivery of new cultivars to users
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1. Breeding Materials Delivery to user

components.label: 1. Who is responsible for making the final decision to release a new cultivar from the breeding program for commercial distribution and use?

values.label: a.) Number and locations of field performance trials?
b.) Verification of performance, identity, trueness-to-type etc. by a governmental agency or unit?
c.) Plans for build-up of Foundation, stock seed, cuttings etc. from breeders’ materials?
d.) Plans for distribution (advertising, marketing, give-away, sale etc. of commercial planting materials?

components.label: 2. What information about a new cultivar is required in order for it to be considered for release?
4. How well is this breeding program linked to a method of distribution for efficiency and effective provision of new materials to farmers?

values.label: a.) Are cultivar releases done in a timely, effective manner?
b.) Are users satisfied with the delivery system?

components.label: 3. What is/are the usual system(s)/procedure(s) used to distribute planting materials of cultivars developed and released by this breeding program? Examples: Gov’t. (state or national) seed distribution network, university-foundation seed organization, commercial company/distributor, NGO’s, etc.
c.) How can release and distribution of new cultivars from this breeding program be improved?

components.title: Module  4: Plant breeding program activities, accomplishments and opportunities
components.label: page20M4A10-assessment10

components.content: Assessment 10 :Trait priorities for cultivar development for key production areas/regions

components.legend: 1.Key Production Area/Region
components.label: M4A10-assessment10Fieldset
Load Areas

In order to meet future program goals and objectives that will satisfy current and future needs for genetically-improved cultivars of this crop in the key production areas/regions , list the important traits for which selection will be performed

components.label: Content

components.content: <b>List the five (5) most important “production” traits, e.g., yield
components.label: Content

components.content: <b>List the three (3) most important “quality” traits that affect acceptance and use of the crop product, e.g,, grain, fruit, etc.
components.label: Content

components.content: <b>Among the previous eight (8) traits, list the two (2) traits that will have greatest effect on acceptance or rejection and use by farmers/growers in this area
components.label: Content

components.content: <b>What is the name of the widely-grown current cultivar(s) that will be used in field trials to compare the performance of new selections and potential cultivars adapted to this area?
components.label: Content

components.title: Module  4 : Plant breeding program activities, accomplishments and opportunities
components.label: page21M4A11-assessment11

components.content: Assessment 11 :Potential new cultivars from spill-ins from other programs
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1.Potential new cultivars from spill-ins from other programs

questions.label: 1.Rate the likelihood of having promising new, untested pre-cultivars COMING INTO your program from other programs IN THIS COUNTRY.
2. Rate the likelihood that promising new, untested pre-cultivars in ARE AVAILABLE from other programs IN THIS COUNTRY
3. Rate the likelihood of having promising new, untested pre-cultivars COMING INTO this program from other countries IN THE REGION
4. Rate the likelihood that promising new, untested pre-cultivars in ARE AVAILABLE from other countries IN THE REGION
5. Rate the likelihood that promising commercial cultivars ARE COMING into this program from other programs IN THIS COUNTRY
6. Rate the likelihood that promising commercial cultivars ARE AVAILABLE from other programs IN THIS COUNTRY
7. Rate the likelihood that promising commercial cultivars ARE COMING into this program from OTHER COUNTRIES IN THE REGION
8. Rate the likelihood that promising commercial cultivars ARE AVAILABLE from OTHER COUNTRIES IN THE REGION

components.label: 9. Please enter any additional comments below

components.title: Module  4 : Plant breeding program activities, accomplishments and opportunities
components.label: page22M4A12-assessment12

components.content: Assessment 12 :New 5- and 10-year goals for your breeding program
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1.New 5- and 10-year goals for your breeding program

components.label: 1. List your overall breeding program goals and objectives for the future five (5) to ten(10)-year period for this crop, taking into account the trait priorities listed in Assessment 10
2. What type(s) of cultivars (e.g., Open Pollinated, F1 Hybrid, inbred/self pollinated, clonal etc.) will be developed and released to farmers/growers?

components.content: Please specify the types of population and their primary improvement traits.
components.label: Content

4. Within the overall breeding program goals and objectives, list and describe briefly the strategies and approaches you will follow to ensure that suitable new cultivars adapted to each of the key production areas/regions that this breeding program serves are developed and released.
3. What are your pre-breeding (population improvement) goals, taking into account the trait priorities listed in Assessment 10?

components.title: Module  5 : Evaluate the human and tangible capital assets currently in the PB program components that contribute to PBC

components.title: Module 5: Evaluate the human and tangible capital assets currently in the PB program components that
components.label: page24M5A14-assessment14

components.content: Assessment 14 :Funding and administration for Breeding Program Operations and Testing
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1. Funding and administration for Breeding Program Operations and Testing

questions.label: 1. Select the level to which the total breeding program budget (expenditures) for current year is sufficient for the breeding program to be productive and successful?
2. Select the level to which the capital items budget (expenditures) for current year is sufficient for the breeding program to be productive and successful?
3. Select the level to which the operational budget (expenditures) for current year is sufficient for the breeding program to be productive and successful?
4. Select the level to which the budget allocation for breeder(s) and staff travel for local program work/testing is sufficient for the breeding program to be productive and successful?

5. Select the level to which the budget allocation for breeder(s) and staff travel (e.g., scientific meetings, other programs, etc.) is sufficient for the breeding program to be productive and successful?
6. Select the level to which the budget allocation for breeder(s) and staff continuing education is sufficient for the breeding program to be productive and successful?
7. What overall grade would you give the budget items above in terms of sufficiency for the breeding program to be productive and successful?

components.label: 8. Please write any additional comments below

components.legend: 2.Administration Information

components.label: 1. Is the breeding program for this crop at this location a separate program in your institute or part of a larger, multi-component program?
2. To whom do the program breeders report, administratively?

3. Are the breeders and other breeding team members evaluated for professional advancement based on breeding accomplishments (e.g., number of varieties released and adopted by farmers, etc.)? If not, how are they evaluated?

components.legend: 3.Budgetary Information

components.label: 1. What percentage of the total breeding program budget for this crop at this location is provided from your institute?
2. What percentage comes from non-continuing competitive grants?
3. Is the percentage coming from your institute reliable each year?
If not, what influences lack of budgetary stability?
4. Does this plant breeding program have a separate budget that is administered by the senior plant breeder?
5. Are there people whose job it is to administer budgets and personnel working in this breeding program?
6. How many breeders' salaries are from funds administered through this program?
7. How many technicians are funded by money administered through this program?
8. How many graduate students are working in this project?
9. What is the total budget (expenditures) in the local currency for this breeding program for the current year?
11. What is the total budget (expenditures) in US dollars for this breeding program for the current year?
12. Does the total budget (expenditures) include the staffing salaries mentioned above?
13. Does this also include capital expenditures?

components.content: 14. What percent of the total budget is used for the following (i.e. 12 = 12%)?
components.label: Content
16. Does the program have a usable vehicle for project travel and other activities?
17. Do field plots have access to supplemental irrigation when needed?
18. Are field plots regularly tended and maintained?
19. For this year's operations, who provides the budget support for multi-location trials away from the main station?
20. For this year's operations, are program activities, such as testing and evaluations at other stations, covered by the breeding budget?
21. For this year's operations, is your current annual budget sufficient to fund on-farm selection and evaluation as part of the breeding program?
15. If the program was allocated a capital budget during the current year, how will it be spent?
4. What incentives are provided for breeding team members who reach objectives/goals?

components.title: Module  5 : Evaluate the human and tangible capital assets currently in the PB program components that contribute to PBC
components.label: page25M5A15-assessment15

components.content: Assessment 15 :Physical Facilities Required for Breeding Operations and Field Testing
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1.Lab facilities at primary breeding facility or station

questions.label: 1. Please select the functional level (maintained and updated regularly) of the program's computers to handle record keeping and data analyses and critical software licenses and packages
2. Please select the functional level of your high speed connectivity to the Internet and to internal units for accessibility, data analysis, and information exchange

3. Please select the functional level of your labs for processing, handling, threshing, cleaning, sorting, weighing, packaging for shipping and storing planting materials (e.g., cuttings, dry or wet seeds)

4. Please select the functional level of your long- and short- term climate controlled facilities (e.g. refrigerator, walk-in cooler, cool, dry rooms for short, medium and long storage of seeds free from pests)
5. Please select the functional level of your labs for handling DNA samples and conducting technology to support marker-assisted breeding (MAB)
6. Please select the functional level of your labs for trangenic engineering
7. Please select the functional level of your labs for cell and tissue culture, clonal propagation and producing doubled haploid plants
8. Please select the functional level of your lab for chemical, physiological, biochemical analyses needed to support goals of the breeding program
9. Please select the functional level of your specialized structures, containers, etc. for screening populations for insect, nematode and disease resistances

components.legend: 2.Field facilities at the central facility to support the breeding program

questions.label: 1. Select the functional level of your necessary field equipment for plot preparation, planting, crop maintenance, harvesting, post-harvest processing etc
2. Select the functional level of your field plots for breeding and selection nurseries near to central facility with good fertility and water control
3. Select the functional level of your field plots for demonstrating advanced performance trials of commercial materials and potential new cultivars to farmers

components.legend: 3.Structures to shelter plants for cross-pollinations to make new segregating populations

questions.label: 1. Select the functional level of your permanent or semi-permanent structures with glass, plastic, or screen enclosures needed for protection of mother plants for crossing.
2. Select the functional level of your screen or polymesh cages needed to control insects for insect pollinated crops

components.legend: 4.Other facilities

questions.label: 1. Select the functional level of your facilities required for foundation and stock seed production of commercial and near-commercial cultivars in use or being released
2. Select the functional level of your facilities required for conducting experiments with regulated materials (e.g. from genetic engineering, quarantined plants, pathogens, etc.)

components.legend: 5.Experiment station facilities for selection and testing in critical target environments

questions.label: 1.Select the functional level of your government/project research stations for early generation selection and testing to meet critical goals
2. Select the functional level of your government/project research stations for adaptation testing of new potential cultivars in critical target environments
3.Select the functional level of your other testing facilities (e.g. extension service and other units)

components.legend: 6.Locations and arrangements with farmers/growers for farmer-assisted breeding activities

questions.label: 1. Select the functional level of your land and arrangements for farmer-assisted selection and/or testing of new cultivars in farmers fields

components.legend: 7.Summary and Comments

questions.label: 1. Select the overall functional level of the previously described physical facilities required for breeding operations and field testing.

components.label: 2. Make any other comments about your physical facilities required for breeding operations and field testing

components.title: Module  5 : Evaluate the human and tangible capital assets currently in the PB program components that contribute to PBC
components.label: page26M5A16-assessment16

components.content: Assessment 16 :Scientific Information and Know-how for crop improvement
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1.Scientific Information and Know-how for crop improvement

questions.label: 1. Please rate the capacity of the knowledge of statistical and experimental design know-how for organization, layout, planting of field plots suitable for supporting scientific decisions about selection and performance of new lines
2. Please rate the capacity of the knowledge of organization, layout and maintenance of parents for crossing blocks, breeding nurseries, etc
3. Please rate the capacity of the knowledge of good plant growing and maintenance practices for the crop in this breeding program
4. Please rate the capacity of the knowledge of methods used for cross pollination, pollination control and production of experimental selection populations for line and new hybrid production
5. Please rate the capacity of the knowledge of analytical methods used for evaluating important traits key to meeting program goals and objectives
6. Please rate the capacity of the knowledge of methods for extracting and handling plant materials and DNA either for analysis in nearby labs or shipment to central facilities elsewhere

7. Please rate the capacity of the knowledge of computer hardware and software for collecting, analyzing, storing and reporting phenotypic and genotypic information and data relevant for this breeding program

8. Please rate the capacity of the knowledge of Methods and procedures for applying for intellectual property protection on new varieties and how to acquire and negotiate use of intellectual property from other sources
9. Please rate the capacity of knowledge of other information or know-how
10. How would you rate the overall knowledge capacity for crop improvement?

components.title: Module  5 : Evaluate the human and tangible capital assets currently in the PB program components that contribute to PBC
components.label: page27M5A17-assessment17

components.content: Assessment 17: Supporting Technology for Crop Improvement
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1.Your breeding program and other breeding and research programs

questions.label: 1. Please rate the capacity and strength of linkages between your breeding program and other programs at the site where your breeding program is located
2. Please rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program and other programs, universities and institutes elsewhere in the country and region
3. Please rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program and regional centers
4. Please rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program and international centers and institutes (e.g. IARC's, etc.)

components.legend: 2.Other organizations for receipt and exchange of technology, plants and planting materials

questions.label: 1. Rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program with other organizations for receipt and exchange of technology, plants and planting materials such as wild relatives and unadapted germplasm?

2. Rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program with other organizations for receipt and exchange of technology, plants and planting materials such as segregating populations created through pre-breeding and germplasm improvement?

3. Rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program with other organizations for receipt and exchange of technology, plants and planting materials such as mutated populations for screening and selection?

4. Rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program with other organizations for receipt and exchange of technology, plants and planting materials such as materials developed through transgenic engineering for enhancement of in?

5. Rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program with other organizations for receipt and exchange of technology, plants and planting materials such as cell and tissue cultures for enhancement of in?

components.legend: 3.Receipt and exchange of information, technology and biomaterials for breeding technology

questions.label: 1. Rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program for receipt and exchange of information, technology and biomaterials for breeding technology such as marker-assisted breeding for enhancement of in?
2. Rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program for receipt and exchange of information, technology and biomaterials for breeding technology such as transgenic engineering?

3. Rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program for receipt and exchange of information, technology and biomaterials for breeding technology such as cell and tissue culture?
4. Rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program for receipt and exchange of information, technology and biomaterials for breeding technology such as clonal propagation?
5. Rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program for receipt and exchange of information, technology and biomaterials for breeding technology such as doubled haploid plants?
6. Rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program for receipt and exchange of information, technology and biomaterials for breeding technology such as induced mutants?

components.legend: 4.Receipt and exchange of information, technology and biomaterials for focused research

questions.label: 1. Rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program for receipt and exchange of information, technology and biomaterials for focused research such as drought tolerance screening and breeding?

2. Rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program for receipt and exchange of information, technology and biomaterials for focused research such as breeding for efficient nutrient utilization?

3. Rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program for receipt and exchange of information, technology and biomaterials for focused research such as disease resistance breeding?

4. Rate the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program for receipt and exchange of information, technology and biomaterials for focused research such as improved nutritional quality of plant products from this crop?

components.legend: 5.Summary and Comments

questions.label: 1. What overall grade would you give the capacity and strength of linkage between your breeding program and supporting technologies previously described?

components.label: 2. Make any comment you have about the capacity and strength of linkage between the breeding program and the supporting technologies

components.title: Module  5 : Evaluate the human and tangible capital assets currently in the PB program components that contribute to PBC
components.label: page28M5A18-assessment18

components.content: Assessment 18 :Plant germplasm and materials and available to the active breeding program
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1.Plant germplasm and materials and available to the active breeding program

questions.label: 1. Rate the capacity to which core collections of plant materials that contribute genetic variability provide germplasm and act as a backup seed source to offset crop failures for this crop

2. Rate the capacity to which cultivars commonly grown in the target production region(s) provide germplasm to the breeding program and act as a backup seed source to offset crop failures for this crop
3. Please rate the capacity to which special materials such as recombinant inbred lines for genetic analyses, mutated populations, other studies, etc. provide germplasm to the breeding program
4. Rate the capacity to which unique segregating F2 populations being selected for target traits critical to success of the breeding program provide germplasm for further breeding
5. Rate the capacity to which unique families (F3 through F7) being selected for further testing provide germplasm for further breeding
6. Please rate the capacity to which advanced, homozygous pure lines in early phases of testing on govt. experiment stations (pure line, OP cultivars) provide germplasm for further breeding
7. Rate the capacity to which elite, homozygous pure lines in late phases of testing on govt. experiment stations or farmers' fields (pureline OP cultivars) provide germplasm for further breeding
8. Rate the capacity to which elite, homozygous pure lines in late phases of farmer-assisted breeding/testing (pureline OP cultivars) provide germplasm for further breeding
9. Rate the capacity to which homozygous or near-homozygous lines being tested as hybrid parents provide germplasm for further breeding
10. Rate the capacity to which advanced hybrids in early phases of testing on govt. stations provide germplasm for further breeding
11. Rate the capacity to which advanced hybrids in late phases of testing on govt. stations or in farmers fields for commercial hybrids provide germplasm for in
12. Rate the capacity to which advanced hybrids in late phases of farmer assisted breeding/testing for commercial hybrids provide germplasm for further breeding

components.legend: 2.Landrace cultivars and planting materials maintained by farmers

questions.label: 1. Rate the capacity to which national and regional cultivars and populations provide germplasm for further breeding
2. Rate the capacity to which local cultivars and populations provide germplasm for further breeding

components.legend: 3.Named cultivars in the seed system from public programs and private companies

questions.label: 1. Rate the capacity to which national and regional universities and institutes of provide germplasm for this breeding program
2. Rate the capacity to which IARC's and other international institutes provide germplasm for this breeding program
3. Rate the capacity to which local and national seed companies provide germplasm for this breeding program
4. Rate the capacity to which multi-national seed companies provide germplasm for this breeding program

components.legend: 4.External germplasm collections in genebanks

questions.label: 1. Rate the capacity to which 's national gene bank provides germplasm for this breeding program
2. Rate the capacity to which plant introductions to this program through bi-, or multi-lateral agreements provide germplasm for for this breeding program
3.Rate the capacity to which accessions and breeding lines from participation in evaluation networks provide germplasm for for this breeding program
4. Rate the capacity to which CGIAR Genebanks provide germplasm for for this breeding program
5. Rate the capacity to which public genebanks in industrialized countries provide germplasm for this breeding program
6. Rate the capacity to which public genebanks in non-industrialized countries provide germplasm for this breeding program
7. Rate the capacity to which private sector businesses, seed companies, other organizations provide germplasm for this breeding program

components.title: Module  5 : Evaluate the human and tangible capital assets currently in the PB program components that contribute to PBC
components.label: page29M5A19-assessment19

components.content: Assessment 19 :Gap Analysis for determining PBC components for a breeding program
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1. Gap Analysis for determining PBC components for a breeding program

questions.label: Physical facilities
Funding for capital improvement
Recurring funding for operations
Plant genetic resources
Supporting technology
Scientific information and know-how
Breeders, assistant breeders, technical assistants
Scientists in supporting disciplines
Budget, administration and personnel managers
Government and stakeholder mandate
Coordination of plant breeding and seed sector
Enabling policies, laws, and regulations
Policy making procedures
Recurring funding arrangements
Management procedures
Links to internal and external organizations
Public and private seed delivery systems
Political, governmental, and economic enablement and support
Extended education and outreach
Bi-directional communication between provider and customers

components.title: Module  6 : Develop an action plan to provide sufficient PBC to support attainment of breeding program objectives and plans
components.label: page30M6A20-assessment20

components.content: Assessment 20 :Guidelines for a plan of action to attain optimum PBC
components.label: Content

components.legend: 1.Guidelines for a plan of action to attain PBC

components.content:
Use the following guidelines and considerations to develop a plan of action to attain optimum PBC for your breeding program.
• Importance of and cost/benefit of outcomes from an objective.
• Needs of growers, handlers, processors, and consumers.
• Non-breeding alternatives that may be more feasible for achieving the result coming from the objective.
• Time lag; feasibility of achieving the objective in a reasonable time.
• Breeder and allied scientists interest, commitment, imagination, foresight, and knowledge of available germplasm, genetic diversity, genes available and trait expressivity in the crop of interest.
• Alternative breeding strategies and options for accomplishing objective (e.g. selecting for yield per se or improving water use efficiency to increase yield or using marker-assisted selection vs. phenotypic selection).
• Intrinsic characteristics of the plant and production system (e.g. reproductive system, economic use and importance, germplasm variability, changing production practices, etc.).
• Political and economical considerations.
Based on the foregoing step-wise assessment of capacity in each of the breeding program components and sub-components:
components.label: Content
1. What are your productivity outcome (PO) goals measured as new, genetically-improved crop cultivars that are distributed to and adopted and grown by farmers? Are they realistic and attainable?
2. What are other productivity outcome (PO) goals (e.g. improved plant populations, research results, breeder training, etc.) of this BP?
3. What are the most critical constraints to attaining your productivity outcome (PO) goals?

4. Is there ongoing, bi-directional flow of information between providers, i.e., breeders and users, i.e., farmers and other critical stakeholders? Is there respect for each others’ ideas? Are the farmers supporting the breeding program either tangibly or
5. Are there enough key personnel in the breeding program and are they sufficiently motivated to foster a low turnover of people and good program continuity?

6. Is there an adequate, reliable, recurring budget for core program activities; salaries and wages, supplies for breeding activities, preparation and care of plots and facilities, computers and data base maintenance, travel for program related activities
7. Are there adequate facilities, budget and know-how for evaluating, selecting and testing new materials, segregating populations and promising advanced selections?
8. For any sub-components that are inadequate, can you propose constructive, attainable changes to improve capacity that should require only organizational changes but no additional funding?

9. If you are provided a sum of money equal to 10% of your current breeding program resources, where (in the sub-components shown above) would you invest that resource in the first year to make the greatest impact on your future productivity outcome (PO)

10. If you are provided a sum of money equal to 25% of your current breeding program resources, where (in the sub-components shown above) would you invest that resource in the first year to make the greatest impact on your future productivity outcome (PO)

11. If you are allowed to double your budget over the next three years, what is your plan for using those resources to attain either sufficient or optimal capacity in as many critical breeding program components and sub-components as feasible?
12. Based on the previous Gap analysis (Assessment 19), verify where the changes you propose to improve PBC will fill the current gaps in breeding program capacity
